docs.lead_paragraph: As I noted in an article Monday, the National Science Foundation wants to reform high school computer science education in America, expanding its reach and updating the curriculum to better prepare students for a 21st-century economy. Professional organizations and major technology companies, including Google, Microsoft and Intel support the broad agenda, though companies are not getting into curriculum details.
docs.abstract: A move to encourage computer education reflects the concern that people will be divided between those who understand technology and those who are ruled by it.
docs.snippet: A move to encourage computer education reflects the concern that people will be divided between those who understand technology and those who are ruled by it....

headline.main: Computer Science Education: It's Not Shop Class

docs.lead_paragraph: They asked for it. And now that politicians appear to have gotten the high numbers of voters many of them sought, they were learning to live with one of the more inconvenient consequences: long, long lines. For the most part, they found their V.I.P status to be of little help. Gov. David A. Paterson, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Senator Charles E. Schumer and Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey all faced mobbed polling places. Mr. Corzine, ever the early riser, arrived at his polling place in Hoboken around 6:15 only to face a wait of an hour and 45 minutes. But at least this time he didn't have to wait because of a voting machine glitch.
docs.abstract: Governors, senators and mayors learn to wait with everyone else, amid the high voter turnout they sought.
docs.snippet: Governors, senators and mayors learn to wait with everyone else, amid the high voter turnout they sought....

headline.main: Political V.I.P.'s Learn How to Wait

docs.lead_paragraph: THE idealized places and social systems we call utopias, after the imaginary island in Sir Thomas More's 1516 work, have had a bad century. Nazism, Communism, suicide cults, fundamentalist theocracies and other extremisms have led to eye-rolling exasperation at utopias in general and linked the concept of an earthly heaven with a dystopian descent into earthly hell. But without idealized goals, life would be apathetic and stagnant. The exhibition ''Utopia: The Search for the Ideal Society in the Western World,'' at the New York Public Library, shows how utopias have an importance that outweighs their impossibility or even looniness. Like third-party candidates, utopias win by losing, as their ideas influence the mainstream.
docs.abstract: Michael Pollak column surveys Web sites devoted to utopias; photo (M)
